Case Name: Amarendra Komalam Vs. Usha Sinha
Issue Presented: Whether an issue already settled in a previous case can be re-litigated.
Facts of the Case: The dispute concerns the renewal clause of a lease agreement executed on 02.09.1978.

Precedent: Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in S.L.P.(C) No. 16513 of 2001.

Case Name: Karnataka Rare Earth Vs. The Senior Geologist
Issue Presented: Dispute over mining lease renewal.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner was granted a mining lease, but its renewal was denied citing environmental concerns.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the government.
Argument: Petitioner claims arbitrary rejection and lack of due process.
Rules: Rule 24A of Mineral Concession Rules, 1960.

Case Name: Rajesh Kumar and Ors Vs. Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors

Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on the necessity of reasoned orders in tax matters.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Surjit Singh
Issue Presented: Applicability of equal pay for equal work doctrine.
Facts of the Case: Daily wage employees sought equal pay as permanent employees despite irregular appointments.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employees.
Argument: State argued that no recruitment process was followed and constitutional norms were not adhered to.
Statute: Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: Service Rules of Punjab Government.
Precedent: Ranbir Singh vs. State of Haryana.
Ratio of the Decision: Employees who worked continuously should receive minimum pay scale.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Courtâ€™s decision.

Case Name: Bengal Enamel Works Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal
Issue Presented: Tax assessment of technical advisorâ€™s remuneration.
Facts of the Case: The company hired a technical advisor and paid him a percentage of profits, leading to a tax dispute.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tax authorities ruled the payments as excessive and disallowed deductions.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the remuneration was justified based on expertise and contribution.
Rules: Section 40A(2) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on reasonable expenses under tax laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Payments made were found excessive and unjustified.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the tax authorityâ€™s decision.

Case Name: Delhi Development Authority Vs. Skipper Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Fraudulent misrepresentation in real estate transactions.
Facts of the Case: The construction company collected money from buyers without having legal authorization to sell the property.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the buyers and ordered refund.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the company misled consumers and violated urban planning regulations.
Rules: Real Estate Development Rules.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on consumer fraud.
Ratio of the Decision: Unethical business practices resulted in liability for the company.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered refunds and penalties against the construction company.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. R. Gandhi
Issue Presented: Validity of setting up National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT).
Facts of the Case: The constitutional validity of creating NCLT and National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) was challenged.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity but suggested modifications in appointments.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the tribunals were established as per constitutional provisions.
Rules: Tribunal Rules under Companies Act.
Precedent: Previous rulings on separation of powers and tribunal independence.
Ratio of the Decision: Tribunals must function independently while adhering to constitutional guidelines.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the validity of NCLT but directed amendments in selection procedures.

Case Name: Lalita Kumari Vs. Government of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Mandatory registration of FIR in cognizable offenses.
Facts of the Case: The police refused to register an FIR despite a cognizable offense being reported.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of mandatory FIR registration.
Argument: Petitioner argued that failure to register an FIR violates fundamental rights.
Rules: Section 154 of CrPC.
Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on police duty in FIR registration.
Ratio of the Decision: FIR must be registered in all cognizable cases without preliminary inquiry.
Ruling: Supreme Court made FIR registration mandatory for cognizable offenses.

Case Name: Shreya Singhal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of Section 66A of the IT Act.
Facts of the Case: Section 66A of the Information Technology Act was challenged for violating free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the provision as necessary for cyber regulation.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the law was vague and led to arbitrary arrests.
Rules: Section 66A of the IT Act.
Precedent: Supreme Court rulings on freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Ratio of the Decision: Vague and broad laws cannot restrict fundamental rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down Section 66A as unconstitutional.

Case Name: Vishaka & Ors Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Workplace sexual harassment and guidelines for prevention.
Facts of the Case: A social organization filed a PIL after a woman was subjected to workplace sexual harassment, seeking protective measures.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed the plea for lack of specific legislation.
Argument: Petitioner argued that absence of a law does not negate the duty to protect fundamental rights.
Rules: Guidelines framed by Supreme Court for workplace harassment.
Precedent: No prior comprehensive ruling on workplace harassment laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Workplace safety is a fundamental right, and guidelines must be established.
Ruling: Supreme Court laid down Vishaka Guidelines for prevention of sexual harassment.

Case Name: Aruna Shanbaug Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legality of passive euthanasia in India.
Facts of the Case: A nurse remained in a vegetative state for over 30 years, leading to a plea for withdrawal of life support.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against euthanasia.
Argument: Petitioner argued that prolonged suffering with no scope of recovery violates dignity.
Rules: Medical Board Review on passive euthanasia.
Precedent: No direct ruling on euthanasia before this case.
Ratio of the Decision: Passive euthanasia may be permitted under strict guidelines.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed passive euthanasia under regulated conditions.

Case Name: Navtej Singh Johar Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of Section 377 IPC regarding LGBTQ+ rights.
Facts of the Case: LGBTQ+ individuals challenged the criminalization of consensual same-sex relationships.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court decriminalized Section 377, but Supreme Court later overturned it.
Argument: Petitioner argued that criminalization violates dignity, equality, and privacy.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on privacy and individual rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Criminalizing private consensual acts violates constitutional freedoms.
Ruling: Supreme Court decriminalized consensual same-sex relationships.

Case Name: Maneka Gandhi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Scope of personal liberty under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitionerâ€™s passport was impounded without giving her a valid reason, raising concerns over personal liberty and due process.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the governmentâ€™s decision.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the action violated Article 21 and the principles of natural justice.
Rules: Any law restricting personal liberty must follow the principles of fairness and due process.
Precedent: Previous rulings on personal liberty and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Any law restricting personal liberty must follow the principles of fairness and due process.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, expanding the scope of Article 21.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Environmental pollution and liability for industrial disasters.
Facts of the Case: The leakage of oleum gas from a factory raised concerns over corporate accountability and environmental safety.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court imposed fines on the company.
Argument: Petitioner argued for stricter environmental regulations and corporate liability.
Rules: Strict liability and absolute liability principles.
Precedent: Bhopal Gas Tragedy case rulings.
Ratio of the Decision: Industries must bear absolute liability for hazardous activities.
Ruling: Supreme Court introduced the â€˜absolute liabilityâ€™ principle for environmental hazards.

Case Name: Olga Tellis Vs. Bombay Municipal Corporation
Issue Presented: Right to livelihood under Article 21 of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Slum dwellers challenged eviction orders that would leave them homeless and without a means of livelihood.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of municipal authorities.
Argument: Petitioner argued that forced eviction violated the fundamental right to life and livelihood.
Rules: Municipal regulations on encroachment.
Precedent: Previous rulings on right to shelter.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to livelihood is an integral part of the right to life.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the state must provide reasonable alternatives before eviction.

Case Name: Indra Sawhney Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Validity of OBC reservations and the concept of 'creamy layer'.
Facts of the Case: The Mandal Commission recommended 27% reservation for Other Backward Classes (OBCs), which was challenged for exceeding the reservation limit.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the reservation policy.
Argument: Petitioner argued that excessive reservations violated the principles of equality.
Rules: Reservation guidelines under government policy.
Precedent: Previous rulings on affirmative action and social justice.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservation is valid but must exclude the 'creamy layer' to maintain fairness.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld OBC reservations with the exclusion of the creamy layer.

Case Name: Minerva Mills Ltd. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Balancing Directive Principles and Fundamental Rights.
Facts of the Case: Amendments to the Constitution were challenged for violating the basic structure doctrine.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the constitutional amendments.
Argument: Petitioner argued that amendments cannot destroy fundamental rights.
Rules: Basic structure doctrine established in Kesavananda Bharati case.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala.
Ratio of the Decision: Directive Principles cannot override Fundamental Rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down parts of the amendment as unconstitutional.

Case Name: ADM Jabalpur Vs. Shivkant Shukla
Issue Presented: Suspension of fundamental rights during Emergency.
Facts of the Case: During the Emergency (1975-77), citizens were detained without trial, raising concerns about the right to life and liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of detained individuals.
Argument: Petitioner argued that fundamental rights could be suspended during an Emergency.
Rules: Emergency Provisions under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on state power during national emergencies.
Ratio of the Decision: State has overriding power during Emergency, even over fundamental rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the suspension of fundamental rights during Emergency (later overruled in later cases).

Case Name: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Extent of Parliament's power to amend the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged land reform laws and questioned whether Parliament could alter fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the land reform laws.
Argument: Petitioner argued that Parliament cannot alter the basic structure of the Constitution.
Rules: Doctrine of Basic Structure.
Precedent: No previous ruling on limiting constitutional amendments.
Ratio of the Decision: Parliament cannot alter the basic structure of the Constitution.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the basic structure doctrine, limiting Parliamentâ€™s power to amend the Constitution.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Taj Trapezium Case)
Issue Presented: Protection of the Taj Mahal from environmental pollution.
Facts of the Case: Industrial pollution around the Taj Mahal was causing damage to the monument, prompting environmental litigation.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court directed industries to take pollution-control measures.
Argument: Petitioner argued for relocation of polluting industries to protect the Taj Mahal.
Rules: Air and Water Pollution Control Rules.
Precedent: Previous rulings on environmental protection and heritage conservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Historic sites must be protected from environmental hazards.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered relocation of polluting industries around the Taj Mahal.

Case Name: DK Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Guidelines for the protection of arrested individuals.
Facts of the Case: Incidents of custodial torture and deaths in police custody led to a petition for preventive measures.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court suggested guidelines for custodial safety.
Argument: Petitioner argued for mandatory safeguards to prevent custodial violence.
Rules: Guidelines for arrest and detention procedures.
Precedent: Cases on human rights and police accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights extend to arrested individuals, ensuring protection from custodial abuse.
Ruling: Supreme Court issued mandatory guidelines for arrests and custodial treatment.

Case Name: Lily Thomas Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Disqualification of convicted legislators.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the validity of Section 8(4) of the Representation of the People Act, which allowed convicted legislators to continue in office while appealing their conviction.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the provision allowing legislators to hold office.
Argument: Petitioner argued that convicted legislators should be disqualified immediately to maintain integrity in governance.
Rules: Disqualification rules for convicted individuals.
Precedent: Previous rulings on electoral reforms and political accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: Allowing convicted legislators to continue in office violates democratic principles.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down Section 8(4), making immediate disqualification mandatory for convicted legislators.

Case Name: Peopleâ€™s Union for Civil Liberties Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Right to privacy in telephone tapping cases.
Facts of the Case: PUCL challenged government policies allowing phone tapping, arguing that it violated privacy rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the governmentâ€™s power to tap phones for national security reasons.
Argument: Petitioner argued that unrestricted phone tapping violates Article 21 and fundamental rights.
Rules: Surveillance and interception rules.
Precedent: Previous cases on privacy and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Phone tapping is an invasion of privacy and requires strict safeguards.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that phone tapping requires procedural safeguards to prevent misuse.

Case Name: S. R. Bommai Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Scope of Presidentâ€™s rule under Article 356.
Facts of the Case: The Karnataka government was dismissed by the President under Article 356, raising concerns over misuse of central authority.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the dismissal.
Argument: Petitioner argued that Article 356 should not be misused to dismiss elected governments arbitrarily.
Rules: Doctrine of federalism and judicial review.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the limits of presidential power.
Ratio of the Decision: Presidentâ€™s rule must be subject to judicial review to prevent arbitrary dismissals.
Ruling: Supreme Court placed restrictions on the use of Article 356 and allowed judicial review of dismissals.

Case Name: Mohd. Ahmed Khan Vs. Shah Bano Begum
Issue Presented: Right of a Muslim woman to maintenance under Section 125 CrPC.
Facts of the Case: Shah Bano, a 62-year-old Muslim woman, was divorced by her husband and denied maintenance. She filed a case under Section 125 of the CrPC, which applies to all religions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of Shah Bano, granting her maintenance.
Argument: Petitioner argued that Muslim personal law does not provide for maintenance beyond the iddat period.
Rules: Section 125 of CrPC and Muslim Personal Law.
Precedent: Previous rulings on maintenance rights for divorced women.
Ratio of the Decision: A Muslim woman is entitled to maintenance under Section 125 CrPC if she is unable to support herself.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision, granting Shah Bano maintenance.

Case Name: I. R. Coelho Vs. State of Tamil Nadu
Issue Presented: Whether laws placed in the Ninth Schedule are subject to judicial review.
Facts of the Case: The government placed certain laws in the Ninth Schedule to shield them from judicial review, raising concerns over fundamental rights violations.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the protection granted under the Ninth Schedule.
Argument: Petitioner argued that laws violating fundamental rights should not be protected from judicial review.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 31B and Ninth Schedule.
Rules: Doctrine of Basic Structure.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati case on judicial review.
Ratio of the Decision: Laws placed in the Ninth Schedule must adhere to the Basic Structure of the Constitution.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that laws in the Ninth Schedule are subject to judicial review if they violate fundamental rights.

Case Name: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Environmental pollution due to tanneries in Tamil Nadu.
Facts of the Case: Tanneries in Tamil Nadu were polluting water sources, causing severe environmental damage and affecting public health.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ordered compensation for affected individuals.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the â€˜polluter paysâ€™ principle should be applied to industries responsible for environmental damage.
Rules: Polluter Pays Principle and Precautionary Principle.
Precedent: Previous rulings on environmental conservation and corporate responsibility.
Ratio of the Decision: Industries must bear the cost of preventing and remedying environmental damage.
Ruling: Supreme Court applied the Polluter Pays Principle and ordered compensation and stricter regulations.

Case Name: Naz Foundation Vs. Government of NCT of Delhi
Issue Presented: Decriminalization of homosexuality under Section 377 IPC.
Facts of the Case: Naz Foundation challenged Section 377 of the IPC, arguing that it criminalized consensual same-sex relationships and violated fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: Delhi High Court ruled that Section 377 was unconstitutional as it violated Article 21.
Argument: Petitioner argued that criminalizing homosexuality violated the right to privacy, dignity, and equality.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21.
Precedent: Previous rulings on personal liberty and privacy.
Ratio of the Decision: Criminalizing private consensual acts violates the fundamental rights of individuals.
Ruling: Delhi High Court decriminalized homosexuality, but the ruling was later overturned by the Supreme Court in 2013 (later restored in Navtej Johar case in 2018).

Case Name: Puttaswamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Right to privacy as a fundamental right.
Facts of the Case: The Aadhaar scheme was challenged on the grounds that it violated the right to privacy by collecting personal biometric data.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the Aadhaar scheme as constitutionally valid.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the right to privacy is an essential part of the right to life and personal liberty under Article 21.
Rules: Fundamental Rights and Data Protection Laws.
Precedent: Previous cases on individual autonomy and state surveillance.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to privacy is a fundamental right under the Indian Constitution.
Ruling: Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the right to privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21.

Case Name: Keshub Mahindra Vs. Union of India (Bhopal Gas Tragedy Case)
Issue Presented: Corporate liability for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy.
Facts of the Case: Thousands of people died due to a gas leak from the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, raising concerns about corporate accountability and compensation.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court imposed penalties but reduced criminal liability.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the disaster was an accident and not due to negligence.
Rules: Corporate Liability and Compensation Laws.
Precedent: MC Mehta case on environmental liability.
Ratio of the Decision: Companies handling hazardous substances have absolute liability for accidents.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that Union Carbide was responsible and ordered compensation for the victims.

Case Name: Golaknath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament has the power to amend fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, arguing that Parliament could not amend fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Parliamentâ€™s power to amend the Constitution.
Argument: Petitioner argued that fundamental rights are sacrosanct and cannot be amended by Parliament.
Rules: Doctrine of implied limitations on constitutional amendments.
Precedent: No prior ruling restricting Parliamentâ€™s amendment powers.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights cannot be amended by Parliament.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that Parliament cannot curtail fundamental rights, but this was later overruled in Kesavananda Bharati case.

Case Name: Union Carbide Corporation Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Adequacy of compensation for Bhopal Gas Tragedy victims.
Facts of the Case: The Indian government and Union Carbide reached a settlement for $470 million as compensation for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy victims.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court approved the settlement but faced opposition from victims' groups.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the settlement was fair and should not be re-evaluated.
Rules: Principles of absolute liability and victim compensation.
Precedent: Previous cases on industrial disaster liability.
Ratio of the Decision: The compensation amount should be fair and sufficient for victims.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the settlement but allowed further claims for additional compensation.

Case Name: Sheela Barse Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Rights of women prisoners and custodial violence.
Facts of the Case: Sheela Barse, a journalist, reported the ill-treatment of women prisoners in Maharashtra, leading to a PIL on their rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court issued some reforms but did not mandate strict guidelines.
Argument: Petitioner argued that women prisoners faced inhumane treatment and needed protection.
Rules: Guidelines for prisoner rights and custodial safety.
Precedent: DK Basu case on custodial violence.
Ratio of the Decision: Women prisoners must be protected from abuse, and strict monitoring is needed.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered comprehensive reforms for the treatment of women prisoners.

Case Name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Bonded labor and human rights violations.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed to address the issue of bonded laborers working in inhumane conditions without proper wages.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ordered some relief but did not frame a broader policy.
Argument: Petitioner argued that bonded labor violated fundamental rights and required urgent state intervention.
Rules: Human Rights and Labor Welfare Laws.
Precedent: Previous rulings on forced labor and minimum wages.
Ratio of the Decision: Bonded labor is unconstitutional and must be eradicated.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed the government to implement policies for bonded laborers' rehabilitation.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Krishna Kumar
Issue Presented: Right to education and reservation policies.
Facts of the Case: The state governmentâ€™s education policy was challenged for denying reservations to a certain category of students.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the students seeking reservations.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the policy was justified based on financial and administrative constraints.
Rules: Reservation policies under education laws.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservations.
Ratio of the Decision: Equal access to education is a fundamental right, and reservations should be implemented fairly.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the state must ensure fair reservation policies in education.

Case Name: Ramesh Dalal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Disqualification of MPs and MLAs upon conviction.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the practice of allowing convicted legislators to continue in office while their appeal was pending.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the existing provisions allowing legislators to continue until the appeal process was exhausted.
Argument: Petitioner argued that allowing convicted politicians to remain in office undermines democratic values.
Rules: Disqualification of convicted individuals from public office.
Precedent: Lily Thomas case on electoral disqualification.
Ratio of the Decision: A convicted legislator should be immediately disqualified from holding office.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that convicted MPs and MLAs are disqualified immediately upon conviction.

Case Name: Mohini Jain Vs. State of Karnataka
Issue Presented: Right to education and capitation fees.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the practice of private medical colleges charging high capitation fees for admission.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the private colleges' right to charge fees.
Argument: Petitioner argued that education is a fundamental right and should not be dependent on financial capability.
Rules: Regulation of private educational institutions.
Precedent: Unni Krishnan case on the right to education.
Ratio of the Decision: Education is a fundamental right, and capitation fees violate the principle of equal access.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that capitation fees are unconstitutional, reinforcing the right to education.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Madhukar Narayan Mardikar
Issue Presented: Right to privacy and protection of womenâ€™s dignity.
Facts of the Case: A woman was denied legal protection due to her being a prostitute, raising questions about equal rights and dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the womanâ€™s right to legal protection.
Argument: Petitioner argued that a womanâ€™s profession should not impact her fundamental rights.
Rules: Fundamental Rights and Womenâ€™s Protection Laws.
Precedent: Cases on gender equality and right to dignity.
Ratio of the Decision: Every woman, regardless of profession, has the right to legal protection and dignity.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the right to dignity and privacy applies to all women equally.

Case Name: Jarnail Singh Vs. Lachhmi Narain Gupta
Issue Presented: Reservation in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Facts of the Case: The validity of reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees was challenged.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against blanket reservations in promotions.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the government must collect quantifiable data before granting reservation in promotions.
Rules: Reservation policies in public employment.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservations in promotions require quantifiable data proving backwardness.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the need for data-based reservation policies in promotions.

Case Name: Gian Kaur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of Section 306 IPC (abetment of suicide).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the provision criminalizing abetment of suicide, arguing that the right to life includes the right to die.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court struck down Section 306 IPC as unconstitutional.
Argument: Petitioner argued that individuals have autonomy over their own lives, including the right to end them.
Rules: Right to Life under Article 21.
Precedent: P. Rathinam case on suicide laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to life does not include the right to die.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the validity of Section 306 IPC, ruling that abetment of suicide remains a crime.

Case Name: K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) Vs. Union of India (Aadhaar Case)
Issue Presented: Whether Aadhaar violates the fundamental right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the mandatory linking of Aadhaar to various services, arguing it infringed on the right to privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the Aadhaar requirement.
Argument: Petitioner argued that Aadhaar collection and linkage violated individual autonomy and privacy rights.
Rules: Aadhaar Act, 2016.
Precedent: Previous rulings on privacy and personal autonomy.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to privacy is a fundamental right and must be protected against arbitrary state action.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Aadhaarâ€™s validity but restricted its mandatory use in many areas.

Case Name: Shayara Bano Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of instant triple talaq.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the practice of instant triple talaq, arguing that it violated gender justice and fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld triple talaq as valid under Muslim personal law.
Argument: Petitioner argued that instant triple talaq is arbitrary and discriminatory against Muslim women.
Rules: Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937.
Precedent: Previous rulings on gender equality and religious practices.
Ratio of the Decision: Instant triple talaq is arbitrary and unconstitutional.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down instant triple talaq as unconstitutional.

Case Name: Common Cause Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Legalization of passive euthanasia and living wills.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought the legalization of passive euthanasia and the right to make living wills.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court denied the right to passive euthanasia.
Argument: Petitioner argued that individuals should have the right to refuse artificial life support.
Rules: Guidelines for passive euthanasia and living wills.
Precedent: Aruna Shanbaug case on euthanasia.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to die with dignity is a part of the right to life.
Ruling: Supreme Court legalized passive euthanasia and recognized living wills.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Kamal Nath
Issue Presented: Environmental damage due to private development projects.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the diversion of a river and encroachment on forest land for a private resort.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court imposed fines but allowed the project to continue.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the project violated environmental laws and affected the ecosystem.
Rules: Doctrine of Public Trust.
Precedent: Previous environmental rulings on public trust and sustainability.
Ratio of the Decision: Natural resources belong to the public and cannot be misused for private gain.
Ruling: Supreme Court applied the Public Trust Doctrine and ordered restoration of the damaged area.

Case Name: State of Tamil Nadu Vs. K. Balu
Issue Presented: Ban on liquor shops near highways.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed seeking a ban on liquor shops along highways to reduce road accidents caused by drunk driving.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the existing liquor licensing policies.
Argument: Petitioner argued that unrestricted liquor sales along highways posed a serious risk to public safety.
Rules: Liquor Licensing Rules and Road Safety Regulations.
Precedent: Cases on state control over liquor regulation.
Ratio of the Decision: Public safety takes precedence over commercial interests.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered a ban on liquor shops within 500 meters of highways.

Case Name: Delhi Transport Corporation Vs. DTC Mazdoor Congress
Issue Presented: Validity of arbitrary termination of employees.
Facts of the Case: DTC employees were dismissed from service without following due process, leading to a challenge on grounds of natural justice.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employees, ordering reinstatement.
Argument: Petitioner argued that termination decisions were within the managementâ€™s discretion.
Rules: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Precedent: Previous rulings on wrongful termination and natural justice.
Ratio of the Decision: Termination must follow due process and principles of natural justice.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Courtâ€™s ruling, ordering reinstatement of employees.

Case Name: State of Uttar Pradesh Vs. Raj Narain
Issue Presented: Right to information and transparency in governance.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought disclosure of government documents related to elections, raising issues of public accountability.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of transparency and ordered document disclosure.
Argument: Petitioner argued that certain documents were confidential and should not be made public.
Rules: Right to Information and Public Accountability Laws.
Precedent: Previous cases on freedom of information.
Ratio of the Decision: Government documents affecting public interest must be accessible to citizens.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the right to information as a fundamental right.

Case Name: M. Nagaraj Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Validity of reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the constitutional validity of reservations in promotions, arguing that it violated meritocracy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the reservation policy.
Argument: Petitioner argued that reservations in promotions should be based on quantifiable data of backwardness.
Rules: Reservation policies in public employment.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservations.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservations in promotions must be justified with quantifiable data.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld reservations in promotions but mandated data collection to justify them.

Case Name: Joseph Shine Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Decriminalization of adultery under Section 497 IPC.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the criminalization of adultery, arguing that it violated gender equality and individual autonomy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of Section 497 IPC.
Argument: Petitioner argued that treating women as property in adultery laws was unconstitutional.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Articles 14, 15, 21.
Precedent: Previous rulings on gender equality and personal liberty.
Ratio of the Decision: Criminalizing adultery violates the right to equality and personal autonomy.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down Section 497 IPC, decriminalizing adultery.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of the Terrorist and Disruptive Activities (Prevention) Act (TADA).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged TADA, arguing that it violated fundamental rights by allowing extended detention without trial.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of TADA.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the provisions of TADA infringed upon the right to liberty and fair trial.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Articles 14, 21.
Precedent: Previous rulings on anti-terror laws and personal liberty.
Ratio of the Decision: While national security is important, fundamental rights cannot be arbitrarily restricted.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld TADA but recommended stricter safeguards to prevent misuse.

Case Name: Nandini Satpathy Vs. P.L. Dani
Issue Presented: Right against self-incrimination during police interrogation.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was asked to answer multiple questions during an interrogation, which she refused, citing her right against self-incrimination.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against the petitioner, stating that refusal to answer could be held against her.
Argument: Petitioner argued that forcing her to answer violated Article 20(3) of the Constitution.
Rules: Right against self-incrimination.
Precedent: Previous cases on self-incrimination protections.
Ratio of the Decision: An accused person cannot be compelled to answer questions that may be self-incriminating.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, strengthening the right against self-incrimination.

Case Name: Sarla Mudgal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Bigamy and conversion to Islam to circumvent marriage laws.
Facts of the Case: A Hindu man converted to Islam solely to marry a second wife without divorcing his first wife, leading to questions about bigamy laws.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the second marriage as valid under Muslim law.
Argument: Petitioner argued that conversion to Islam solely for bigamy purposes should not be permitted.
Rules: Personal laws and bigamy restrictions.
Precedent: Previous rulings on marriage and conversion.
Ratio of the Decision: Conversion should not be misused to bypass personal law restrictions.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that conversion to Islam does not automatically nullify the first marriage.

Case Name: Visakha Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Workplace sexual harassment and absence of laws for protection.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed after a woman was subjected to workplace sexual harassment, demanding legal safeguards.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed the petition, citing lack of specific legislation.
Argument: Petitioner argued that absence of a law does not negate the duty to protect women from harassment.
Rules: Guidelines framed by Supreme Court for workplace harassment.
Precedent: No prior comprehensive ruling on workplace harassment laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Workplace safety is a fundamental right, and guidelines must be established.
Ruling: Supreme Court laid down the Vishaka Guidelines for the prevention of sexual harassment.

Case Name: Bachan Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of the death penalty.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the validity of the death penalty under Section 302 IPC, arguing that it violated fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the death penalty as a valid form of punishment.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the death penalty was arbitrary and violated Article 21.
Rules: Doctrine of 'rarest of rare' cases.
Precedent: Previous cases on capital punishment.
Ratio of the Decision: The death penalty is constitutional but should be imposed only in the 'rarest of rare' cases.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the death penalty with strict limitations.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Dalbir Singh
Issue Presented: Validity of mandatory death sentence under NDPS Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the provision of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act that imposed a mandatory death penalty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the mandatory death sentence provision.
Argument: Petitioner argued that mandatory death sentences violated the right to judicial discretion.
Rules: Sentencing guidelines under criminal law.
Precedent: Bachan Singh case on capital punishment.
Ratio of the Decision: Mandatory death sentences violate the principle of judicial discretion.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down the mandatory death sentence provision.

Case Name: State (Delhi Administration) Vs. Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Another
Respondent: Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Ram Kishan Alias Phokan
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court's acquittal of the accused was legally justified given the evidence on record.
Facts of the Case: Phokan, holding a knife, struggled to escape and called out to Billa. The Delhi High Court overturned the conviction, citing insufficient evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court set aside the conviction and acquitted them.
Argument: Maintained that the prosecution did not establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
Rules: Murder requires conclusive proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
Precedent: No specific precedent mentioned.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that the evidence established the respondents' guilt, and the High Court erred in acquitting them.
Ruling: The Supreme Court overturned the acquittal, convicting both accused under Section 326 IPC and sentencing them to six years of rigorous imprisonment.

Case Name: Ram Saran Dass Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the termination order was a disguised dismissal requiring constitutional protection it was issued in bad faith.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s services were terminated, and he claimed the order amounted to punishment without due process.  The High Court dismissed his petition outright.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Punjab High Court summarily dismissed the petition.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the termination was actually a dismissal requiring constitutional safeguards and that the order was arbitrary.
Rules: Service Rule 23 governing termination of employment.
Precedent: Established case law on procedural fairness and due process in dismissals.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that natural justice required the High Court to allow the respondent to file a response before dismissing the case.
Ruling: The appeal was allowed, and the matter was remanded to allow the respondent to present its case.

Case Name: Credit Agricole Indosuez Vs. Credential Finance Limited
Issue Presented: Whether failure to credit the cheque amount after clearance is grounds for winding up under the Companies Act.
Facts of the Case: The Petitioner, a banking company, maintained the Respondent's account.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Petition was dismissed.
Argument: Likely countered that the cheque was not credited due to legitimate reasons.
Rules: Judicial interpretation of cheque clearance obligations.
Precedent: Case law on cheque clearance and corporate insolvency.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether the non-crediting of a cheque amounts to an inability to pay debts under the law.
Ruling: Appeal filed; further hearings required.

Case Name: A.K. Gopalan Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Validity of preventive detention under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was detained under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, and challenged its constitutionality, arguing that it violated his fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the Preventive Detention Act.
Argument: Petitioner argued that preventive detention without a fair trial violated Article 21.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: No prior ruling on preventive detention laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Article 21 is subject to procedural laws, and preventive detention can be valid if due process is followed.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the Preventive Detention Act but later interpretations expanded Article 21 protections.

Case Name: State of West Bengal Vs. Anwar Ali Sarkar
Issue Presented: Special courts and equality before law under Article 14.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged a law allowing the government to refer cases to special courts, arguing that it violated the right to equality.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court struck down the law as discriminatory.
Argument: Petitioner argued that selective referral to special courts violated Article 14.
Rules: Equality before law and due process.
Precedent: Cases on special courts and non-discrimination.
Ratio of the Decision: Special courts cannot be arbitrary and must follow uniform legal principles.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down the law as unconstitutional.

Case Name: Kedar Nath Singh Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Sedition and freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was convicted under Section 124A IPC (sedition) for making speeches critical of the government.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the conviction for sedition.
Argument: Petitioner argued that sedition laws unreasonably restricted free speech.
Rules: Freedom of speech and reasonable restrictions.
Precedent: Previous cases on sedition and free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Criticism of government policies is not sedition unless it incites violence.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Section 124A but limited its application to speech inciting violence.

Case Name: Bharat Singh Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Validity of land acquisition for public purposes.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the acquisition of agricultural land by the government, arguing it was not for a public purpose.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the land acquisition.
Argument: Petitioner argued that landowners' rights were violated without adequate compensation.
Rules: Public purpose requirement in land acquisition.
Precedent: Previous rulings on land acquisition and compensation.
Ratio of the Decision: Land acquisition must be for a legitimate public purpose with fair compensation.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the government but emphasized fair compensation.

Case Name: Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of the National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC).
Facts of the Case: The NJAC Act was challenged as violating judicial independence.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld NJAC as valid.
Argument: Petitioner argued that NJAC undermined the judiciaryâ€™s independence by giving the executive more control over appointments.
Rules: Judicial appointments under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the separation of powers.
Ratio of the Decision: Judicial independence is a basic structure principle and cannot be diluted.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down NJAC as unconstitutional.

Case Name: Laxmi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Regulation of acid sales and protection of acid attack victims.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed seeking stricter regulations on acid sales and better compensation for acid attack survivors.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court suggested stricter enforcement of existing laws.
Argument: Petitioner argued that easy availability of acid led to frequent attacks and victims lacked support systems.
Rules: Regulations on acid sale and victim rehabilitation.
Precedent: Previous rulings on womenâ€™s safety.
Ratio of the Decision: Stricter regulations on acid sales are necessary to prevent attacks.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered restrictions on acid sales and better compensation for victims.

Case Name: Tamil Nadu Govt. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: State vs. Central government power over education policies.
Facts of the Case: The Tamil Nadu government challenged certain central laws affecting state education policies.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the central government.
Argument: Petitioner argued that education should be a state subject under the Constitution.
Rules: Division of powers between state and center.
Precedent: Previous cases on federalism and education policy.
Ratio of the Decision: Education is a subject where both state and central governments have roles.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld central laws but allowed states flexibility in implementation.

Case Name: Subramanian Swamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of criminal defamation laws.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the validity of Sections 499 and 500 IPC, arguing that they restricted free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld criminal defamation as constitutional.
Argument: Petitioner argued that defamation laws should be a civil matter, not a criminal offense.
Rules: Freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Precedent: Previous cases on defamation laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Reputation is a fundamental right, and defamation laws are a reasonable restriction.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld criminal defamation laws as constitutional.

Case Name: Ram Jawaya Kapur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Extent of executive power under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the Punjab government's action of running a business without legislative authorization.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the government, stating it had the power to act in certain areas.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the executive cannot function independently without legislative approval.
Rules: Doctrine of separation of powers.
Precedent: Previous cases on executive power limits.
Ratio of the Decision: Executive power extends to areas not expressly covered by legislation but cannot override it.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the government's action, defining the limits of executive power.

Case Name: State of Bihar Vs. K.K. Misra
Issue Presented: Right of government employees to strike.
Facts of the Case: Government employees went on strike demanding better wages, which led to disciplinary action against them.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employees, stating that the strike was justified.
Argument: Petitioner argued that government employees do not have an absolute right to strike.
Rules: Essential Services Maintenance Act.
Precedent: Previous rulings on employees' rights and restrictions.
Ratio of the Decision: Government employees cannot claim an absolute right to strike, especially in essential services.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled against the employees, upholding restrictions on strikes.

Case Name: Sundararamier & Co. Vs. State of Andhra Pradesh
Issue Presented: State taxation power and interpretation of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged a state law imposing sales tax on inter-state trade, arguing that it violated the Constitution.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the tax law as valid.
Argument: Petitioner argued that only Parliament has the power to tax inter-state trade.
Rules: Taxation powers under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on fiscal federalism.
Ratio of the Decision: State taxation laws must comply with constitutional limits.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down the state law, reinforcing Parliamentâ€™s exclusive power over inter-state trade taxation.

Case Name: Golak Nath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Can Parliament amend fundamental rights?
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged constitutional amendments that curtailed fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Parliamentâ€™s power to amend fundamental rights.
Argument: Petitioner argued that fundamental rights are beyond the reach of Parliament's amendment power.
Rules: Doctrine of implied limitations.
Precedent: No prior ruling restricting Parliamentâ€™s amendment powers.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights cannot be abridged or taken away by Parliament.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that Parliament cannot curtail fundamental rights, later overruled in Kesavananda Bharati case.

Case Name: Shankarappa Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Censorship powers of the government over films.
Facts of the Case: A film was denied certification by the Censor Board, leading to a legal challenge on free speech grounds.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the Censor Boardâ€™s decision.
Argument: Petitioner argued that government interference in film certification violated Article 19(1)(a).
Rules: Freedom of speech and censorship regulations.
Precedent: Previous cases on media censorship.
Ratio of the Decision: Censorship must be justified on reasonable grounds, not arbitrary state control.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the Censor Board cannot be overridden by the government arbitrarily.

Case Name: Madhu Limaye Vs. Sub-Divisional Magistrate
Issue Presented: Scope of Section 144 CrPC and freedom of speech.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the frequent use of Section 144 CrPC by the government to curb public gatherings and protests.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the use of Section 144 for maintaining public order.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the provision was being misused to stifle free speech and assembly.
Rules: Fundamental rights under Articles 19 and 21.
Precedent: Previous cases on public order and free speech restrictions.
Ratio of the Decision: Section 144 must be used only in exceptional situations and not as a routine measure.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the validity of Section 144 but restricted its arbitrary use.

Case Name: Rupa Ashok Hurra Vs. Ashok Hurra
Issue Presented: Curative petition and judicial review.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought a reconsideration of a Supreme Court judgment after exhausting review petitions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that no further appeal was possible.
Argument: Petitioner argued that courts should have a mechanism to correct gross errors of judgment.
Rules: Scope of curative petitions.
Precedent: Previous cases on judicial finality.
Ratio of the Decision: A curative petition can be entertained in cases of gross miscarriage of justice.
Ruling: Supreme Court introduced the concept of curative petitions for exceptional cases.

Case Name: Shyam Narayan Chouksey Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Compulsory playing of the national anthem in cinemas.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought mandatory playing of the national anthem before movie screenings to instill patriotism.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed the plea, stating it was not a legal necessity.
Argument: Petitioner argued that playing the national anthem promotes national unity and respect.
Statute: Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971.
Rules: Guidelines on national symbols and respect.
Precedent: Previous cases on national symbols and constitutional obligations.
Ratio of the Decision: Citizens must respect the national anthem, but mandatory enforcement is unnecessary.
Ruling: Supreme Court initially made playing the national anthem mandatory but later revised it to optional.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N.M. Thomas
Issue Presented: Reservation in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Facts of the Case: The validity of extending reservations in promotions was challenged, arguing it went beyond constitutional provisions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court struck down the reservation in promotions policy.
Argument: Petitioner argued that social justice measures must extend to promotions for backward classes.
Rules: Reservation policies under public employment laws.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservations.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservation in promotions can be valid if justified for social justice.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld reservation in promotions under specific conditions.

Case Name: Vishwanath Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Dowry death and burden of proof under IPC.
Facts of the Case: A woman died under suspicious circumstances soon after marriage, leading to a case under dowry death laws.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court convicted the accused under dowry death provisions.
Argument: Petitioner argued that mere suspicion should not lead to conviction without strong evidence.
Rules: Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961.
Precedent: Previous cases on dowry death and burden of proof.
Ratio of the Decision: In dowry death cases, burden of proof shifts to the accused under certain circumstances.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the conviction but emphasized the need for strong evidence.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Ganga Pollution Case)
Issue Presented: Industrial pollution in the Ganga River.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed to address the severe pollution in the Ganga River caused by industries and untreated sewage disposal.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court issued directions to control pollution but lacked strict enforcement.
Argument: Petitioner argued that failure to prevent pollution violated the right to a clean environment.
Rules: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974.
Precedent: Previous rulings on environmental protection.
Ratio of the Decision: State is responsible for maintaining clean water bodies and enforcing pollution laws.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered strict monitoring and closure of polluting industries.

Case Name: Govind Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh
Issue Presented: Right to privacy under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged police surveillance, arguing it violated his right to privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the surveillance as necessary for law enforcement.
Argument: Petitioner argued that unrestricted police surveillance intruded upon personal liberty.
Rules: Right to privacy and police procedures.
Precedent: Previous cases on surveillance and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Privacy is a fundamental right but subject to reasonable restrictions for public safety.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld limited surveillance while emphasizing the need for safeguards.

Case Name: Indian Medical Association Vs. V.P. Shantha
Issue Presented: Inclusion of medical services under the Consumer Protection Act.
Facts of the Case: The respondent filed a complaint against medical negligence and sought compensation under consumer law.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that medical services fell under the Consumer Protection Act.
Argument: Petitioner argued that doctors should not be treated as service providers under consumer laws.
Rules: Medical negligence and patient rights.
Precedent: Previous cases on consumer rights and professional services.
Ratio of the Decision: Medical services are covered under consumer laws if provided for consideration.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that patients can sue for medical negligence under the Consumer Protection Act.

Case Name: Peopleâ€™s Union for Democratic Rights Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Enforcement of labor laws in construction projects.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed alleging violation of labor laws in Asiad Games construction projects.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found violations but issued only advisory recommendations.
Argument: Petitioner argued that non-enforcement of labor laws violated fundamental rights of workers.
Rules: Labor rights under the Constitution.
Precedent: Cases on workers' rights and state obligations.
Ratio of the Decision: State has a duty to ensure implementation of labor laws.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed strict enforcement of labor laws and protection of workers' rights.

Case Name: Ramesh Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Ban on a TV serial for allegedly spreading communal disharmony.
Facts of the Case: A complaint was filed seeking a ban on a TV serial for allegedly promoting religious intolerance.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of allowing the broadcast.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the content incited hatred and should be restricted.
Rules: Freedom of speech and reasonable restrictions.
Precedent: Previous cases on media regulation and free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Free speech includes artistic freedom but must not incite violence.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the right to broadcast, subject to monitoring for objectionable content.

Case Name: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. Vs. State of Rajasthan and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the amount of freight in sales of cement under the Cement Control Order  of the Central Sales Tax Act, making it taxable.
Facts of the Case: The Petitioner owns Udaipur Cement Works in Rajasthan and sells cement both within and outside the state.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower authorities included the freight charges as part of the sale price, making it subject to sales tax.
Argument: Contended that freight was part of the price payable by the buyer and should be included in the taxable amount.
Statute: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, 1954.
Rules: Interpretation of sale price under tax laws in controlled commodity sales.
Precedent: Cases discussing whether freight charges constitute part of the sale price for taxation purposes.
Ratio of the Decision: The core legal issue was whether freight charges should be included in the taxable sale price when cement was sold under a government-mandated price structure.
Ruling: The Court's decision was awaited on whether freight should be excluded or included in the sale price for taxation.

Case Name: R.G. Anand Vs. Delux Films
Issue Presented: Copyright infringement in literary and artistic works.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner alleged that the respondentâ€™s film copied the theme, characters, and storyline of his play.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that similarities were coincidental and not substantial.
Argument: Petitioner argued that substantial similarities in theme and expression constituted copyright infringement.
Rules: Doctrine of substantial similarity in copyright law.
Precedent: Previous cases on artistic originality and copyright protection.
Ratio of the Decision: Mere similarity in theme does not constitute copyright infringement unless expression is copied.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled against the petitioner, stating that broad themes are not protected by copyright.

Case Name: Shri Roshanlal Gautam Vs. State Of Uttar Pradesh And Others
Respondent: State of Uttar Pradesh and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the U.P. Government’s decision to nationalize transport services.
Facts of the Case: The Petitioner held a contract carriage permit covering the Agra region.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Allahabad High Court upheld the State’s authority, dismissing the Petitioner's challenge.
Argument: Asserted that the State had full authority under Section 68-C to nationalize routes.
Rules: Extent of State’s authority to revoke private transport permit.
Precedent: Cases interpreting Section 68-C in State transport nationalization.
Ratio of the Decision: The case examined whether private operators had rights against government nationalization.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court's verdict.

Case Name: P. Rathinam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Decriminalization of attempted suicide under Section 309 IPC.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the constitutionality of Section 309 IPC, arguing that punishing attempted suicide violated the right to life and dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of Section 309 IPC.
Argument: Petitioner argued that an individual has the right to end their own life.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: Previous cases on personal autonomy and state intervention.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to life does not include the right to die.
Ruling: Supreme Court initially struck down Section 309 IPC but later upheld its validity in Gian Kaur case.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Dispute over financial allocations between state and central government.
Facts of the Case: Karnataka challenged the central government's allocation of funds under federal financial distribution policies.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the central government.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the state's financial rights were being unfairly curtailed.
Rules: Federalism and financial distribution laws.
Precedent: Previous cases on fiscal federalism.
Ratio of the Decision: Financial allocation must be equitable and in accordance with constitutional provisions.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the central government's financial distribution policy but recommended fairer allocation mechanisms.

Case Name: Rajbala Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of educational qualifications for contesting local body elections.
Facts of the Case: Haryana amended its Panchayati Raj Act to impose minimum educational qualifications for contesting local body elections, which was challenged as discriminatory.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the amendment as constitutional.
Argument: Petitioner argued that imposing educational qualifications violated the right to equality and restricted political participation.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 14.
Precedent: Cases on electoral rights and reasonable restrictions.
Ratio of the Decision: Educational qualifications for elections do not violate the Constitution if they serve a rational purpose.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the Haryana law, ruling that it was a reasonable classification.

Case Name: Municipal Board, Manglaur Vs. Sri Mahadeoji Maharaj
Issue Presented: Whether the vacant land adjacent to a public road vested in the Municipality or was private property.
Facts of the Case: Municipality planned to build structures on the vacant site adjacent to the road.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court ruled in favor of the plaintiff, granting a permanent injunction and possession.
Argument: Land was private property. Land was part of a public road and vested in the Municipality.
Statute: Municipal governance laws governing public roads and adjacent land.
Rules: Extent of Municipal authority over public roads and adjacent land.
Precedent: Prior rulings on roadways and adjacent land ownership.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether the vacant land adjacent to the road was private or public property.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court’s decision.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. Association for Democratic Reforms
Issue Presented: Voter's right to know candidate's criminal background.
Facts of the Case: A petition was filed demanding mandatory disclosure of candidates' criminal records, assets, and liabilities before elections.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that such disclosure was necessary for an informed electorate.
Argument: Petitioner argued that compulsory disclosure was unnecessary and violated the right to privacy.
Rules: Electoral transparency and accountability laws.
Precedent: Previous rulings on electoral reforms and voter rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Voters have the right to know the background of candidates they are electing.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated disclosure of candidatesâ€™ criminal records and financial details.

Case Name: Jindal Stainless Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of entry tax imposed by states.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the imposition of entry tax by state governments, arguing it violated free trade between states.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the stateâ€™s right to impose entry tax.
Argument: Petitioner argued that entry tax restricted interstate commerce and was unconstitutional.
Rules: Free trade and commerce clauses under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on taxation and free trade.
Ratio of the Decision: States have the right to impose entry tax, provided it does not hinder free trade.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the validity of entry tax, ruling that states have the power to regulate trade.

Case Name: M/S Japan Airlines Co. Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Respondent: Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Issue Presented: Whether landing and parking fees should be treated as rent for the purpose of tax deduction at source (TDS).
Facts of the Case: Japan Airlines paid airport charges for runway maintenance, landing services, and security.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Income Tax Department upheld its view that landing and parking charges fall under rent, making TDS applicable.
Argument: The payments involve use of airport land, thus falling under rent.
Statute: Section 194-I of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
Rules: Whether aviation-related services fall under rent as per Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Court rulings on whether airport charges fall under rental income.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether comprehensive aviation services can be taxed as rent.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court’s decision.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Jagjit Singh
Issue Presented: Equal pay for equal work for temporary employees.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, a temporary government employee, claimed equal pay as that of a permanent employee for performing similar duties.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employee, granting equal pay.
Argument: Petitioner argued that temporary employees are not entitled to the same benefits as regular employees.
Rules: Principle of equal pay for equal work.
Precedent: Previous cases on temporary employee rights.
Ratio of the Decision: If temporary employees perform the same duties as permanent employees, they are entitled to equal pay.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Courtâ€™s decision, enforcing the principle of equal pay for equal work.

Case Name: Kailas & Others Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Honor killing and criminal liability.
Facts of the Case: The petitioners were convicted for killing a couple who married against societal norms, raising the issue of whether honor killings should be treated as separate offenses.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the conviction under murder charges.
Argument: Petitioner argued that social customs should be considered in sentencing.
Rules: Criminal laws on murder and sentencing.
Precedent: Previous rulings on honor killings and severe punishment.
Ratio of the Decision: Honor killings must be treated as murder with strict punishment.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld life imprisonment for the accused, emphasizing deterrence against honor killings.

Case Name: Krishna Pillai Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Whether illegal smuggling of gold and subsequent confession of guilt should lead to conviction under the Land Customs Act.
Facts of the Case: Krishna Pillai was caught smuggling gold from Pondicherry into India.
Ruling by Lower Court: Trial Court found Krishna Pillai guilty.
Argument: The accused was caught smuggling gold, justifying his conviction.
Statute: Section 7(1)(b) of the Land Customs Act, 1924.
Rules: Any goods transported without customs permission are subject to confiscation.
Precedent: Cases involving unauthorized transport of dutiable goods across borders.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether a confession of smuggling should be considered sufficient evidence for conviction.
Ruling: High Court found issues with how the confession was obtained, upheld the sentence, but reversed the confiscation of gold.

Case Name: State of Rajasthan Vs. Jagannath
Issue Presented: Land encroachment and eviction laws.
Facts of the Case: The respondent was accused of encroaching on government land, leading to a dispute over eviction laws and rehabilitation.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against the respondent and ordered eviction.
Argument: Petitioner argued that state land cannot be occupied without proper authorization.
Rules: Eviction and land protection policies.
Precedent: Previous rulings on unauthorized land occupation.
Ratio of the Decision: Illegal encroachment must be removed, but proper rehabilitation should be considered.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld eviction but directed the state to provide rehabilitation where necessary.

Case Name: National Legal Services Authority Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Recognition of transgender rights and legal status.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed to recognize transgender individuals as a third gender and secure their fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of transgender rights but did not mandate specific policies.
Argument: Petitioner argued that denial of legal recognition violated dignity and equal protection under the law.
Rules: Human rights and gender identity laws.
Precedent: Previous rulings on minority rights and dignity.
Ratio of the Decision: Transgender individuals must be legally recognized and granted equal rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court recognized transgender individuals as the third gender and directed the government to implement inclusive policies.

Case Name: Mithu Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of mandatory death penalty under Section 303 IPC.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the mandatory death penalty imposed under Section 303 IPC for offenders serving life imprisonment.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the provision as valid.
Argument: Petitioner argued that a mandatory death sentence violated the right to life and judicial discretion.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: Previous cases on sentencing guidelines.
Ratio of the Decision: Mandatory death penalty is unconstitutional as it eliminates judicial discretion.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down Section 303 IPC, declaring it unconstitutional.

Case Name: D.K. Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Guidelines for protection against custodial violence.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed highlighting cases of custodial torture and deaths, seeking preventive measures.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court recommended procedural reforms but did not issue binding guidelines.
Argument: Petitioner argued that lack of safeguards led to unchecked police brutality.
Rules: Custodial safety and police accountability regulations.
Precedent: Cases on human rights and police excesses.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights extend to detainees, and custodial abuse must be prevented.
Ruling: Supreme Court issued strict guidelines for arrest and custodial treatment.

Case Name: Ajay Hasia Vs. Khalid Mujib Sehravardi
Issue Presented: Whether government-funded institutions fall under 'State' under Article 12.
Facts of the Case: A technical institute was accused of discriminatory admission practices, raising the issue of whether it was covered under Article 12.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that the institute did not qualify as 'State' under Article 12.
Argument: Petitioner argued that institutions receiving substantial government funding should be treated as State.
Rules: Interpretation of 'State' in fundamental rights cases.
Precedent: Previous cases on public institutions and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Institutions heavily funded and controlled by the government fall under 'State' under Article 12.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the technical institute was covered under Article 12 and bound by fundamental rights.

Case Name: Narmada Bachao Andolan Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Environmental impact and displacement due to dam construction.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed against the construction of the Sardar Sarovar Dam, citing large-scale displacement and ecological damage.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the project, citing developmental needs.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the dam violated environmental and rehabilitation policies.
Rules: Resettlement and Rehabilitation Guidelines.
Precedent: Previous cases on environmental and human rights concerns.
Ratio of the Decision: Development projects must balance ecological concerns and rehabilitation needs.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the damâ€™s construction but mandated strict rehabilitation measures.

Case Name: The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Vs. S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Respondent: S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether remittances under the agreement constituted taxable income for S. K. F. under Indian tax laws.
Facts of the Case: It was an agent for foreign corporations, selling goods on their behalf.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court determined that S. K. F. acted as an agent, and only remittances after sales proceeds were realized were taxable.
Argument: S. K. F. was merely disguising profits as remittances. Remittances were not part of the agent’s profit but a transfer of funds to the principal.
Statute: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-Tax Act.
Rules: The sale proceeds belong to the principal, but the timing of remittances affects tax liability.
Precedent: Cases defining whether an agent’s remittances are taxable.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether sale proceeds collected by an agent are liable to taxation before remittance.
Ruling: Supreme Court overturned the High Court ruling, clarifying that remittances made under contractual obligation were not taxable as profits.

Case Name: Turner Morrison And Co., Ltd Vs. Hungerford Investment Trust Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether the plaintiff's claim for reimbursement and interest was legally justified.
Facts of the Case: Turner Morrison sued Hungerford for reimbursement of super tax payments and interest, claiming a lien on 2,295 shares. The defendant countered that no legal obligation existed for reimbursement.
Ruling by Lower Court: Ruled that Turner Morrison had not sufficiently proven the tax payment, and the claim was barred by waiver and limitation.
Argument: Asserted its right to recover super tax payments with interest.
Statute: Contract law, taxation principles, and legal doctrines of waiver, estoppel, and limitation.
Rules: Voluntary payments without contractual obligation cannot be reimbursed, and claims barred by limitation cannot be enforced.
Precedent: Cases involving estoppel, waiver, and limitation in financial claims.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether Turner Morrison’s claim was legally enforceable or barred by limitation and estoppel.
Ruling: Dismissed the appeal, stating that no valid claim.

Case Name: M/S. Corporate Ispat Alloys Limited Vs. M/S. Jayaswal Neco Industries Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the Company Court should proceed with the winding-up petition.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that arbitration does not bar winding-up proceedings.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court deferred consideration, citing the arbitration process as a reason for postponement.
Argument: The Company Court deferred consideration, citing the arbitration process as a reason for postponement.
Rules: The court must determine insolvency independently without relying solely on arbitration.
Precedent: Judicial interpretations stating that arbitration proceedings cannot override winding-up petitions.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether Company Courts should wait for arbitration outcomes before deciding on insolvency.
Ruling: Clarified that arbitration proceedings alone do not justify delaying a winding-up petition.

Case Name: National Organic Chemical Inds. Ltd Vs. Miheer H. Mafatlal
Issue Presented: Whether the Company Court overstepped its jurisdiction by addressing the title of individual shareholders.
Facts of the Case: The Company Court still ruled the allotment was invalid, citing the City Civil Court's injunction.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court should not have examined share ownership issues under Sections 391-394.
Argument: The Company Court erred in ruling on the validity of share allotment.
Rules: A City Civil Court's injunction does not automatically bind the Company Court’s decisions.
Precedent: Courts have previously ruled that company courts should not decide on share ownership disputes in merger proceedings.
Ratio of the Decision: Whether share ownership disputes must follow a separate rectification process.
Ruling: Clarified that shareholder disputes must follow statutory rectification procedures.

Case Name: Anjuman Islamia and Others Vs. Munshi Tegh Ali and Others
